title.narrative: IAS WASH-IWRM COVID-19 Intervention: Transforming the Vulnerable Disabled into Able Responders in Leri and Umm Durein, South Kordofan State

description.narrative:
IAS will implement this project in Al Leri and Umm Durein in South Kordofan, targeted Um Dorein accessible parts ( Alhamra, Higer Afool, Alatmoor and Almushtaraka). There are overwhelming basic needs for most of the population as Alirri has a number of refugees and Um Dorein locked for long time. This project targets 35,460 direct beneficiaries and approximately another 20,250 indirect beneficiaries of mainly destitute host community, returnees from conflict in emerging areas, and pastorals. The main objective of this project is to contribute to saving and protecting lives (especially vulnerable children, women and disabled citizens), while increasing the resilience of protracted displacement groups and addressing malnutrition, livelihood needs and education infrastructure, through an Integrated Water Resource Management solution intervention, responding to immediate water, sanitation and hygiene, and protection needs and gaps for more than 55,000 direct and indirect beneficiaries, while mitigating the COVID19 pandemic in Leri and Umm Durein Localities, South Kordofan State, Sudan. The role of targeting the disabled is a key facet of this intervention. Th disabled will not only be given humanitarian support, but will be recruited to help design, plan, and participate in project activities, including monitoring amp evaluations hence the title ."..Able Responders" - the disabled in these communities will no longer be considered or consider themselves as useless and pitied, but as respected, participants and contributors. Wash activities include the construction (with beneficiary participation)of four solar-powered mini water yards with added pipe extensions to serve potential livelihood needs as well as the schools and reproductive health centers in the area. Current water points will be surveyed for highest water yields to support the MWYs. IAS will drill 5 new boreholes with 5 new hand pumps after surveying the region with our geologist using a terremeter to discover safe water sources underground. Representatives of diverse backgrounds within communities will be consulted to ensure that chosen locations will not start conflicts between rival groups. 12 hand pump rehabilitations will be completed. Piped water will serve 4 Health Centers and Schools. 4 hand-washing units for schools and health centers made of strong Tiga with taps and cooler and thermal bricks. IAS will construct four new 6 drop latrines for the Health Centers and schools. They will be gender sensitive and disability-friendly. All water and sanitation hard components are to provide safe water to be used by patients and staff of the Health Centers, schools, as well as the host communities. To improve sanitation and hygiene practices IAS will also provide Sanitation and Hygiene Awareness and cross-cutting issues training to community committees who will then share with the remainder of targeted beneficiaries. Each new or rehabilitated water point will be maintained and operated by Water Management Committees (WMCs), 50% women who will also receive mechanic training to ensure operation and maintenance of water points. The project includes a cash-based incentive for purchasing tool repair kits to be used by the WMCs for maintaining water-points. The disabled will be involved by collecting water usage fees and monitoring and evaluating construction and training classes. More sanitation needs will be met by the beneficiary centered Community Led Total Sanitation (CLTS) campaigns in 4 villages. 10 Mass Media campaigns will be conducted by girls, boys, women men and those with disabilities in an effort to advocate and inform communities about the looming COVID19 pandemic threat using hundreds of IEC materials.
